elements.content: Two copper­(I) halide-based coordination polymers, namely, [Cu3Cl2(Tipa)2]Cl (1, (Tipa = tris­(4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)­phenyl)­amine) and [Cu3I3(CuI)2(Tipa)3] (2), were obatined under the solvothermal reactions, respectively. Compound 1 with the chain structure shows unique Cu···Cu interactions, C–H···Cl halogen hydrogen bonds, and π···π stacking interactions. It also exhibits unusual mechanochromic and photocatalytic properties on degradation of methylene blue (MB).
elements.clean_text: Two copper(I) halide-based coordination polymers, namely, [Cu3Cl2(Tipa)2]Cl (1, (Tipa = tris(4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)phenyl)amine) and [Cu3I3(CuI)2(Tipa)3] (2), were obatined under the solvothermal reactions, respectively. Compound 1 with the chain structure shows unique Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu interactions, C-H⋅⋅⋅Cl halogen hydrogen bonds, and π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions. It also exhibits unusual mechanochromic and photocatalytic properties on degradation of methylene blue (MB).

elements.content:
The halide-modulated Cu­(I) coordination polymers (CPs) showed the unique mechanochromism and photocatalytic properties.

Introduction

Recently, coordination polymers (CPs) that possess fascinating structures and unique luminescent and catalytic properties have been systemically studied. Among these CPs, only a few Cu­(I) CPs can act as mechano-responsive luminescent materials, displaying incredible behavior like mechanochromism and solvato/vapochromism in response to the external stimulus effects. To date, the rational design of CPs with mechanochromic responsive behavior is still a great challenge, as the photoluminescent mechanism of CPs has not been clearly elucidated. Noteworthy some traditional mechanochromic materials including the polynuclear noble metal complexes (such as Pt­(II), Au­(III), and Ag­(I)) have displayed distinguished photophysical properties. However, the complicated fabrication procedure and high cost limit their potential application. In our previous report, we found that copper­(I) CPs based on N-heterocyclic bridging ligands like boron imidazolate and tetrazolate showed unusual mechanochromic behavior. To enlarge the π-system of these N-heterocyclic ligands and replace the expensive noble metals, we try to introduce the Cu­(I) salt in reaction with a new tris­(4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)­phenyl)­amine) (Tipa) ligand for novel functional CPs construction. To the best of our knowledge, the first syntheses of the title compounds suggest the possibilities of designing new Cu­(I) halide CPs with tunable abilities of different structures and properties by introducing different halide ions under Tipa ligand system.
elements.clean_text:
The halide-modulated Cu(I) coordination polymers (CPs) showed the unique mechanochromism and photocatalytic properties.

Introduction

Recently, coordination polymers (CPs) that possess fascinating structures and unique luminescent and catalytic properties have been systemically studied. Among these CPs, only a few Cu(I) CPs can act as mechano-responsive luminescent materials, displaying incredible behavior like mechanochromism and solvato/vapochromism in response to the external stimulus effects. To date, the rational design of CPs with mechanochromic responsive behavior is still a great challenge, as the photoluminescent mechanism of CPs has not been clearly elucidated. Noteworthy some traditional mechanochromic materials including the polynuclear noble metal complexes (such as Pt(II), Au(III), and Ag(I)) have displayed distinguished photophysical properties. However, the complicated fabrication procedure and high cost limit their potential application. In our previous report, we found that copper(I) CPs based on N-heterocyclic bridging ligands like boron imidazolate and tetrazolate showed unusual mechanochromic behavior. To enlarge the π-system of these N-heterocyclic ligands and replace the expensive noble metals, we try to introduce the Cu(I) salt in reaction with a new tris(4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)phenyl)amine) (Tipa) ligand for novel functional CPs construction. To the best of our knowledge, the first syntheses of the title compounds suggest the possibilities of designing new Cu(I) halide CPs with tunable abilities of different structures and properties by introducing different halide ions under Tipa ligand system.

elements.content: In this work, we report two copper­(I) halide based CPs, [Cu3Cl2(Tipa)2]­Cl (1) and [Cu3I3(CuI)2(Tipa)3] (2). The phase purity and stability of two complexes were demonstrated by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA; Figures S1and S2), respectively. Interestingly, halide ions play an important role in tuning the CPs structure and physical properties. Complex 1 shows unusual mechanochromic and photocatalytic properties on degradation of methylene blue (MB). Complex 2 exhibits an intriguing three-dimensional (3D) structure incorporating rhombic Cu2I2 dimers.
elements.clean_text: In this work, we report two copper(I) halide based CPs, [Cu3Cl2(Tipa)2]Cl (1) and [Cu3I3(CuI)2(Tipa)3] (2). The phase purity and stability of two complexes were demonstrated by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA; Figures S1and S2), respectively. Interestingly, halide ions play an important role in tuning the CPs structure and physical properties. Complex 1 shows unusual mechanochromic and photocatalytic properties on degradation of methylene blue (MB). Complex 2 exhibits an intriguing three-dimensional (3D) structure incorporating rhombic Cu2I2 dimers.

elements.content: X-ray crystal structure analysis reveals that 1 is a cationic one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymer and crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit consists of two copper­(I) ions, one chloride, and one Tipa ligand. The Cu1 shows a trigonal geometry, coordinated by two N atoms from two Tipa ligands and one Cl– ion, whereas Cu2 exhibits a linear fashion, being coordinated by two N atoms from two Tipa ligands.
elements.clean_text: X-ray crystal structure analysis reveals that 1 is a cationic one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymer and crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit consists of two copper(I) ions, one chloride, and one Tipa ligand. The Cu1 shows a trigonal geometry, coordinated by two N atoms from two Tipa ligands and one Cl- ion, whereas Cu2 exhibits a linear fashion, being coordinated by two N atoms from two Tipa ligands.

elements.content: All reagents were purchased and used without further purification. Thermal stability test was performed on a NETSCHZ STA-449C thermoanalyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under an N2 atmosphere. Mini Flex-II diffractometer recorded the PXRD analyses by Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.540 56 Å) with a step size of 0.05°. PerkinElmer Lambda 35 spectrophotometer was chosen to monitor the degradation of MB in solution by 1. An Ultima-2 spectrometer was used to research inductively coupled plasma (ICP). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction investigation were performed on a computer-controlled Super Nova CCD diffractometer. Crystal data as well as details of data collection and refinement for 1 and 2 are summarized in .
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Instrumentation

All reagents were purchased and used without further purification. Thermal stability test was performed on a NETSCHZ STA-449C thermoanalyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under an N2 atmosphere. Mini Flex-II diffractometer recorded the PXRD analyses by Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) with a step size of 0.05°. PerkinElmer Lambda 35 spectrophotometer was chosen to monitor the degradation of MB in solution by 1. An Ultima-2 spectrometer was used to research inductively coupled plasma (ICP). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction investigation were performed on a computer-controlled Super Nova CCD diffractometer. Crystal data as well as details of data collection and refinement for 1 and 2 are summarized in .

elements.content:

ωR 2 = [∑w(F o 2 – F c 2)/∑w(F o 2)2]1/2.

A mixture of Tipa (0.0427 g, 0.1 mmol), CuI (0.0294 g, 0.15 mmol), proline (0.0132 g, 0.1 mmol), dimethylformamide (DMF; 4 mL), MeOH (1 mL), and H2O (1 mL) were placed in a vial. The sample was heated at 100 °C for 6 d and then cooled to room temperature. Gray crystals of 1 were collected by filtration, washed with water, and air-dried (yield: 41% based on CuCl). IR (KBr cm–1): 3855 (w), 3744 (w), 3674 (w), 3440 (w), 3106 (w), 1655 (w), 1610 (w), 1516 (s), 1456 (m), 1303 (m), 1281­(m), 1130 (w), 1064 (m), 965 (w), 830 (m), 731 (w), 650 (w), 542 (w). Elemental analysis for 1: (%): Calcd: C, 54.77; H, 3.55; N, 16.58. Found: C, 54.28; H, 3.51; N, 16.91. 2 was obtained by the above method as described for 1 by using CuI instead of CuCl (yield: 27% based on CuI). IR (KBr cm–1): 3854 (w), 3746 (w), 3674 (w), 3116 (w), 1655 (w), 1608 (w), 1516 (s), 1304 (m), 1123 (w), 1060 (m), 962 (w), 828 (w), 731 (w), 653 (w), 542 (w). Elemental analysis for 2: (%): Calcd: C, 42.64; H, 2.76; N, 12.89. Found: C, 42.16; H, 3.04; N, 12.81.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of (1) and (2)

A mixture of Tipa (0.0427 g, 0.1 mmol), CuI (0.0294 g, 0.15 mmol), proline (0.0132 g, 0.1 mmol), dimethylformamide (DMF; 4 mL), MeOH (1 mL), and H2O (1 mL) were placed in a vial. The sample was heated at 100 °C for 6 d and then cooled to room temperature. Gray crystals of 1 were collected by filtration, washed with water, and air-dried (yield: 41% based on CuCl). IR (KBr cm-1): 3855 (w), 3744 (w), 3674 (w), 3440 (w), 3106 (w), 1655 (w), 1610 (w), 1516 (s), 1456 (m), 1303 (m), 1281(m), 1130 (w), 1064 (m), 965 (w), 830 (m), 731 (w), 650 (w), 542 (w). Elemental analysis for 1: (%): Calcd: C, 54.77; H, 3.55; N, 16.58. Found: C, 54.28; H, 3.51; N, 16.91. 2 was obtained by the above method as described for 1 by using CuI instead of CuCl (yield: 27% based on CuI). IR (KBr cm-1): 3854 (w), 3746 (w), 3674 (w), 3116 (w), 1655 (w), 1608 (w), 1516 (s), 1304 (m), 1123 (w), 1060 (m), 962 (w), 828 (w), 731 (w), 653 (w), 542 (w). Elemental analysis for 2: (%): Calcd: C, 42.64; H, 2.76; N, 12.89. Found: C, 42.16; H, 3.04; N, 12.81.

elements.content: The evaluation of photocatalytic activities of 1 for methyl blue (MB) was tested at room temperature. The detailed steps were as follows: (1) 0.020 g of crystal 1 was dispersed into 20 mL of MB water solution (15.00 mg·L–1); (2) followed by three drops of H2O2 solution (30%); (3) the mixture was stirred continuously with a magnetic stirrer under a 500 W xenon arc lamp; (4) at different time intervals (0–15 min), six samples were tested by UV/vis spectroscopy, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Photocatalytic Experiment

The evaluation of photocatalytic activities of 1 for methyl blue (MB) was tested at room temperature. The detailed steps were as follows: (1) 0.020 g of crystal 1 was dispersed into 20 mL of MB water solution (15.00 mg⋅L-1); (2) followed by three drops of H2O2 solution (30%); (3) the mixture was stirred continuously with a magnetic stirrer under a 500 W xenon arc lamp; (4) at different time intervals (0-15 min), six samples were tested by UV/vis spectroscopy, respectively.

elements.content: Coordination polymer 1 is the presence of fused 32-membered [Cu2(Tipa)2)] macrocycle [10.552(4) × 10.470(3) Å]. The macrocycles are further connected by two coordinated Cu atoms to create an infinite chain. Interestingly, disordered Cl– anions are located in the cavities (a). The Cu···Cu distance between two adjacent chains is 3.251 Å, which approaches to double that of the van der Waals radius (1.40 Å) of a Cu+ center. There are C–H···Cl and π···π interactions between two imidazole planes from ligands of adjacent chains, and the nearest C–H···Cl and π···π distances are 2.830 and 3.494 Å, respectively (b). Further, these interactions make the neighbor chains pack into a supramolecular structure.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Coordination polymer 1 is the presence of fused 32-membered [Cu2(Tipa)2)] macrocycle [10.552(4) × 10.470(3) Å]. The macrocycles are further connected by two coordinated Cu atoms to create an infinite chain. Interestingly, disordered Cl- anions are located in the cavities (a). The Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance between two adjacent chains is 3.251 Å, which approaches to double that of the van der Waals radius (1.40 Å) of a Cu+ center. There are C-H⋅⋅⋅Cl and π⋅⋅⋅π interactions between two imidazole planes from ligands of adjacent chains, and the nearest C-H⋅⋅⋅Cl and π⋅⋅⋅π distances are 2.830 and 3.494 Å, respectively (b). Further, these interactions make the neighbor chains pack into a supramolecular structure.

elements.content: (a) 1D chain structure of 1. (b) Image of the structure between adjacent rings (Cu···Cu interaction: red dashed line). Color codes: Cu, pale blue; Cl, green; C, black; N, blue. To clarify, some atoms are removed.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) 1D chain structure of 1. (b) Image of the structure between adjacent rings (Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu interaction: red dashed line). Color codes: Cu, pale blue; Cl, green; C, black; N, blue. To clarify, some atoms are removed.

elements.content: To further study the influence of the halide ionic for self-assembly of the copper­(I) halide CPs, we performed control experiments by introducing different copper­(I) halide CuX (X = F–, Br–, and I–, respectively) under the similar solvothermal conditions. However, only complex 2 was synthesized successfully. Compound 2 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c, and there are five independent copper­(I) ions, five iodides, and three Tipa groups in the coordination environments (a). Cu1, Cu3, and Cu5 are tetrahedrally coordinated with Cu–I and Cu–N distances in the range of 2.604–2.899 Å and 1.990–2.064 Å, respectively. Triangular coordinated Cu2 is coordinated by three I atoms with Cu–I distances of 2.494–2.632 Å and I–Cu–I angles of 115.45–123.32°. The remaining Cu4 is coordinated by one iodine atom and two N atoms. In complex 2, the most remarkable structural feature is the presence of two independent [Cu2I2] rhomboid dimers linked by Cu3I3 in the 3D framework (b,c). The topology analysis suggests that the whole framework features (3, 4, 6)-connected network with the topology symbol (4.82)­2­(42.54.84.9 × 104)­(5.8.9 × 103)­2­(8 × 102)­2­(82.10)­2­(82.9)­2 by possessing tripodal Tipa ligands as 3-connected nodes, the [Cu2I2] clusters as 6-connected nodes, and the Cu atom as 3- and 4-connected nodes (d).
elements.clean_text: To further study the influence of the halide ionic for self-assembly of the copper(I) halide CPs, we performed control experiments by introducing different copper(I) halide CuX (X = F-, Br-, and I-, respectively) under the similar solvothermal conditions. However, only complex 2 was synthesized successfully. Compound 2 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c, and there are five independent copper(I) ions, five iodides, and three Tipa groups in the coordination environments (a). Cu1, Cu3, and Cu5 are tetrahedrally coordinated with Cu-I and Cu-N distances in the range of 2.604-2.899 Å and 1.990-2.064 Å, respectively. Triangular coordinated Cu2 is coordinated by three I atoms with Cu-I distances of 2.494-2.632 Å and I-Cu-I angles of 115.45-123.32°. The remaining Cu4 is coordinated by one iodine atom and two N atoms. In complex 2, the most remarkable structural feature is the presence of two independent [Cu2I2] rhomboid dimers linked by Cu3I3 in the 3D framework (b,c). The topology analysis suggests that the whole framework features (3, 4, 6)-connected network with the topology symbol (4.82)2(42.54.84.9 × 104)(5.8.9 × 103)2(8 × 102)2(82.10)2(82.9)2 by possessing tripodal Tipa ligands as 3-connected nodes, the [Cu2I2] clusters as 6-connected nodes, and the Cu atom as 3- and 4-connected nodes (d).

elements.content: (a) The coordination environments of copper­(I) atoms in 2; (b) the Cu2I2 dimers building units; (c) a single 3D structure; (d) simplified topologies. Color codes: I, pink; Cu, blue; C, gray; N, blue; and partial H atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) The coordination environments of copper(I) atoms in 2; (b) the Cu2I2 dimers building units; (c) a single 3D structure; (d) simplified topologies. Color codes: I, pink; Cu, blue; C, gray; N, blue; and partial H atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: At room temperature, the luminescence properties of two CPs were studied. 1 and 2 show blue and red emissions with the emission maximum wavelength at 455 nm (a) and 725 nm (Figure S3) upon excitation at 365 and 370 nm, respectively. As shown in Figure S4, the maximum of emission band is observed at 410 nm (λex = 375 nm) for the free Tipa ligand. According to previous reports, the emissions of two complexes may be a metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT), which leads to the Cu···Cu [3d–4s] cluster-centered excited state. The luminescence change by grounding was due to the unique chain structural feature of 1. The ground sample of 1 displayed the obvious blue shift at ∼50 nm (λem = 405 nm, a,c). This clear luminescence shift suggested that 1 exhibited the mechanochromism. To analyze the ground sample, its PXRD pattern was investigated. The PXRD showed that the compound 1 lost its original crystallinity because of very weak reflections. Actually, the crystal lattice was disrupted quickly by the grinding with time, because there was a crystal-to-amorphous phase conversion under external force stimulus. After more than one month, PXRD displayed the ground sample was recovered the original crystalline by immersing into the alcohol solvent (d). Mechanochromism may be related to thermochromism; we also investigated its photoluminescence spectra under different temperature conditions. The result showed that only the luminescence intensity grew with declining temperature (b). In most of the discrete zero-dimensional (0D) noble metal complexes and copper complexes, the mechanochromism under grinding was proved to be due to the fluctuation of intermolecular weak interactions. In addition, it has been reported that a slight alteration in the stacking type of extended π-electron conjugated organic compounds may lead to luminescence change. In Cu­(I) coordination polymers, our group found that Cu–Cu interactions and π–π or C–H···π interactions play important roles on tuning luminescence properties. Therefore, it is not hard to understand that luminescent blue-shift phenomenon should be due to the structural modification. It is mainly because 1 is a chain structure, and there were obvious Cu···Cu interactions, C–H···Cl interactions, and π···π interactions between chains in the structure; the alteration of these weak interactions may lead to luminescence change.
elements.clean_text: At room temperature, the luminescence properties of two CPs were studied. 1 and 2 show blue and red emissions with the emission maximum wavelength at 455 nm (a) and 725 nm (Figure S3) upon excitation at 365 and 370 nm, respectively. As shown in Figure S4, the maximum of emission band is observed at 410 nm (λex = 375 nm) for the free Tipa ligand. According to previous reports, the emissions of two complexes may be a metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT), which leads to the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu [3d-4s] cluster-centered excited state. The luminescence change by grounding was due to the unique chain structural feature of 1. The ground sample of 1 displayed the obvious blue shift at ~50 nm (λem = 405 nm, a,c). This clear luminescence shift suggested that 1 exhibited the mechanochromism. To analyze the ground sample, its PXRD pattern was investigated. The PXRD showed that the compound 1 lost its original crystallinity because of very weak reflections. Actually, the crystal lattice was disrupted quickly by the grinding with time, because there was a crystal-to-amorphous phase conversion under external force stimulus. After more than one month, PXRD displayed the ground sample was recovered the original crystalline by immersing into the alcohol solvent (d). Mechanochromism may be related to thermochromism; we also investigated its photoluminescence spectra under different temperature conditions. The result showed that only the luminescence intensity grew with declining temperature (b). In most of the discrete zero-dimensional (0D) noble metal complexes and copper complexes, the mechanochromism under grinding was proved to be due to the fluctuation of intermolecular weak interactions. In addition, it has been reported that a slight alteration in the stacking type of extended π-electron conjugated organic compounds may lead to luminescence change. In Cu(I) coordination polymers, our group found that Cu-Cu interactions and π-π or C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions play important roles on tuning luminescence properties. Therefore, it is not hard to understand that luminescent blue-shift phenomenon should be due to the structural modification. It is mainly because 1 is a chain structure, and there were obvious Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu interactions, C-H⋅⋅⋅Cl interactions, and π⋅⋅⋅π interactions between chains in the structure; the alteration of these weak interactions may lead to luminescence change.

elements.content: (a) Normalized emission spectra (λex = 365 nm) (unground: blue line, ground: black line); (b) photoluminescence spectra of 1 at different temperatures (150–500 K); (c) photographs of 1 showed luminescence changes with grinding time under ambient light and 365 nm UV lamp, respectively; (d) the PXRD pattern of 1 under different test conditions.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Normalized emission spectra (λex = 365 nm) (unground: blue line, ground: black line); (b) photoluminescence spectra of 1 at different temperatures (150-500 K); (c) photographs of 1 showed luminescence changes with grinding time under ambient light and 365 nm UV lamp, respectively; (d) the PXRD pattern of 1 under different test conditions.

elements.content: Inspired by our previous study, photocatalytic activities of 1 were also explored due to the presence of the unsaturated active metal sites. In aqueous solution, obviously 1 exhibited photocatalytic efficiency for MB degradation under xenon arc conditions. The photocatalytic activity of 1 was greatly improved when time increased to 12 min. After 15 min, almost 95% MB was degraded (a,b). The photocatalytic efficiency slightly decreased after three times cycling experiment (c). ICP-AES (AES = atomic emission spectroscopy) showed copper ionic concentration was 8 mg/L after three cycle test. It may be due to a handful crystal sample decomposed under the degradation process. However, the PXRD patterns of 1 remained almost unchanged (d). These excellent results showed that compound 1 can act as a visible-light photocatalyst.
elements.clean_text: Inspired by our previous study, photocatalytic activities of 1 were also explored due to the presence of the unsaturated active metal sites. In aqueous solution, obviously 1 exhibited photocatalytic efficiency for MB degradation under xenon arc conditions. The photocatalytic activity of 1 was greatly improved when time increased to 12 min. After 15 min, almost 95% MB was degraded (a,b). The photocatalytic efficiency slightly decreased after three times cycling experiment (c). ICP-AES (AES = atomic emission spectroscopy) showed copper ionic concentration was 8 mg/L after three cycle test. It may be due to a handful crystal sample decomposed under the degradation process. However, the PXRD patterns of 1 remained almost unchanged (d). These excellent results showed that compound 1 can act as a visible-light photocatalyst.

elements.content: (a) Time-dependent photo-decomposition of MB. (inset) Color change photograph image of MB solution. (b) Photo-decomposition of MB dye in solution under indifferent condition. (c) The three times photocatalytic activities test. (d) The PXRD patterns of 1 after recycling test for MB.

(c) The three times photocatalytic activities test. (d) The PXRD patterns of 1 after recycling test for MB.

elements.content: In summary, two copper­(I) halide-based coordination polymers have been solvothermally obtained and structurally characterized. Compound 1 with unsaturated active metal sites and dynamic structural characteristic showed unusual mechanochromic and photocatalytic properties. In addition, the low-dimensional to high-dimensional transformation involving the anions preference was discovered. The satisfied results may provide good insights into the potential applications of halide-based Cu­(I) coordination polymers in mechanochromic and photocatalytic materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, two copper(I) halide-based coordination polymers have been solvothermally obtained and structurally characterized. Compound 1 with unsaturated active metal sites and dynamic structural characteristic showed unusual mechanochromic and photocatalytic properties. In addition, the low-dimensional to high-dimensional transformation involving the anions preference was discovered. The satisfied results may provide good insights into the potential applications of halide-based Cu(I) coordination polymers in mechanochromic and photocatalytic materials.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of (1) and (2)

A mixture of Tipa (0.0427 g, 0.1 mmol), CuI (0.0294 g, 0.15 mmol), proline (0.0132 g, 0.1 mmol), dimethylformamide (DMF; 4 mL), MeOH (1 mL), and H2O (1 mL) were placed in a vial. The sample was heated at 100 °C for 6 d and then cooled to room temperature. Gray crystals of 1 were collected by filtration, washed with water, and air-dried (yield: 41% based on CuCl). IR (KBr cm-1): 3855 (w), 3744 (w), 3674 (w), 3440 (w), 3106 (w), 1655 (w), 1610 (w), 1516 (s), 1456 (m), 1303 (m), 1281(m), 1130 (w), 1064 (m), 965 (w), 830 (m), 731 (w), 650 (w), 542 (w). Elemental analysis for 1: (%): Calcd: C, 54.77; H, 3.55; N, 16.58. Found: C, 54.28; H, 3.51; N, 16.91. 2 was obtained by the above method as described for 1 by using CuI instead of CuCl (yield: 27% based on CuI). IR (KBr cm-1): 3854 (w), 3746 (w), 3674 (w), 3116 (w), 1655 (w), 1608 (w), 1516 (s), 1304 (m), 1123 (w), 1060 (m), 962 (w), 828 (w), 731 (w), 653 (w), 542 (w). Elemental analysis for 2: (%): Calcd: C, 42.64; H, 2.76; N, 12.89. Found: C, 42.16; H, 3.04; N, 12.81.
